DIV1.P: THE SHEEP-SHEARING: A DRAMATIC PASTORAL. IN THREE ACTS. TAKEN FROM SHAKESPEARE. As it is performed at the THEATRE ROYAL IN THE HAY-MARKET.
LONDON: Printed for G. KEARSLY, No. 46, FLEET-STREET. M,DCC,LXXVII.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. The Country by the Sea-side. A storm. The Clown holloes.
DIV3.P: I Wou'd there was no age between eighteen and three-and-twenty; or that youth wou'd sleep out the rest: for there is nothing in the between, but getting wenches with child, stealing and fighting— The horns sound at a distance Hark you now! wou'd any but these boil'd brains of two-and-twenty hunt this weather! they have scar'd away two of my best sheep, which, I fear, the wolf will sooner find than the master; if any where I have 'em, 'tis by the sea side, browzing of ivy.—Yet I'll tarry till my son come: He hallow'd, but even now—Whoa! ho—hoa—

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Hailloa! hoa!

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: What, art so near? What ail'st thou man?

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: I have seen such a sight!

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Why, boy, how is it?

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: I wou'd you did but see how the sea chafes, how it rages, how it rakes up the shore—but I am not to say it is a sea, for it is now the sky; betwixt the firmament and it you cannot thrust a bodkin's point.—But O the most piteous cry of the poor souls, sometimes to see 'em, and not to see 'em— But then, the ship—to see how the sea flap-dra∣gon'd it—but first how the poor souls roar'd, and the sea mock'd 'em—Then the ship, now boring the moon with her main mast, and anon swallow'd with yest and froth, as you'd thrust a cork into a hogshead.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Name of mercy! when was this, boy?

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Now, now, I have not wink'd since I saw it; the men are yet cold under water.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD. SHEP.
SP.P: Wou'd I had been by the ship side to have help'd 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P:
Look! look, father—there are two of 'em cast ashore, and crawling up the rock—now they are
down again—poor souls, they have not strength to keep their hold—I will go help them.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Run, run, boy! thy legs are youngest.

SP.SPEAKER: CLEOMINES.
SP.P: Bear up, my liege;—again welcome on shore.

SP.SPEAKER: LEONTES.
SP.P: Where are my other friends?—What, perish'd all!

SP.SPEAKER: CLEOMINES.
SP.P: Not a soul sav'd! ourselves are all our crew.

SP.SPEAKER: LEONTES.
SP.L: Laud we the gods! yet wherefore perish'd they,
Innocent souls! and I, with all my guilt,
Live yet to load the earth?

SP.SPEAKER: CLEOMINES.
SP.P: Waste not your small remaining strength of bo∣dy in warring with your mind. Here's help at hand—Good day, old man——

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Never said in worse time—a better to both your worships—command us, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: You have been sweetly soak'd; give the gods thanks that you are alive to feel it.

SP.SPEAKER: LEONTES.
SP.P: We are most thankful, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: CLEOMINES.
SP.P: What desarts are these same?

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: The desarts of Bohemia.

SP.SPEAKER: LEONTES.
SP.L: Say'st thou Bohemia? ye gods, Bohemia!
In ev'ry act your judgments are sent forth
Against Leontes!—Here to be wreck'd and sav'd!
Upon this coast!—All the wrongs I have done,
Stir now afresh within me—Did I not
Upon this coast expose my harmless infant—
Bid Polixenes (falfly deem'd the father)
To take his child—O hell-born jealousy!
All but myself innocent—and now
Upon this coast—

SP.SPEAKER: CLEOMINES.
SP.L: Good Sir, be calm:
What's gone, and what's past help, shou'd be past grief;
You do repent these things too sorely.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: The sea has quite wash'd away the poor gentle∣man's brains. Come, bring him along to our farm, and we'll give you both a warm bed and dry cloathing.

SP.SPEAKER: CLEOMINES.
SP.P: Good shepherd, shew us to the cottage.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: This way, this way—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. Another part of the Country.

DIV1.HEAD: SONG.
DIV1.L: When daffadils begin to peere
With hey the doxey over the dale,
Why then comes in the sweet o'th' year,
For the red blood reigns o'er the winter's pale.
The Lark that tira, lira chaunts
With hey for hey;
The Thrush and the Jay
Are summer songs for me and my aunts,
As we lie tumbling on the hay.

DIV3.P: I once serv'd Prince Florizel, and in my time wore three-pile, but now am out of service. My traffic is sheets; when the kite builds, look to les∣ser linen.

DIV1.HEAD: SONG.
DIV1.L: The white sheet bleaching on the hedge;
With hey the sweet birds, O how they sing!
Doth set my progging tooth on edge;
For a pot of ale is a dish for a King.

DIV3.P: My father nam'd me Autolicus, being litter'd under Mercury; who, s I am, was likewise a snapper-up of unconsider'd trifles; with dice and drab I purchas'd this comparison, and my revenue is the silly cheat—for the life to come, I sleep out the thought of it—a prize! a prize!

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Let me see, every eleven weather tods—every tod yields pound, and odd shilling; fifteen hun∣hundred shorn—what comes the wool to?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: If the springe hold, the cock's mine.Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: I can't do't without counters—Let me see, what am I to buy for our sheep-shearing feast?— Three pounds of sugar, five pounds of currants, rice—What will this sister of mine do with rice? but my father has made her mistress of the feast, and she lays it on.—She hath made me four and twenty nosegays for the shearers—I must have saf∣fron to colour the warden pies—mace—dates— none—that's out of my note; nutmegs, seven; a race or two of ginger, but that I may beg; four pounds of prunes, and as many raisins o'th' sun.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Oh! that ever I was born!

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: In the name of me—

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: O help me, help me: Pluck but off these rags, and then death, death—

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Alack, poor soul, thou hast need of more rags to lay on thee, rather than to have these off.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, the loathsomeness of 'em offend me, more than the stripes I have receiv'd; which are mighty ones, and millions—

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Alas, poor man! a million of beating may come to a great matter.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: I am robb'd, Sir, and beaten; my money and apparel ta'en from me, and these detestable things put upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: What, by a horseman or a footman?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: A footman, sweet Sir; a footman.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Indeed he should be a footman, by the garments he has left with thee. If this be a horseman's coat, it hath seen very hot service—Lend me thy hand, I'll help thee. Come, lend me thy hand.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Oh, good Sir, tenderly—Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Alas, poor soul!

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: O! good Sir; softly, good Sir; I fear, Sir, my shoulder blade is out.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: How now, can'st stand?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Softly, dear Sir; good Sir, softly; you ha'done me a charitable office.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Dost lack any money? I have a little money for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: No, good, sweet Sir; no, I beseech you, Sir; I have a kinsman not past three quarters of a mile hence, unto whom I was going; I shall there have money, or any thing I want—Offer me no money, I pray you, that kills my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: What manner of fellow was he that robb'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: A fellow, Sir, that I have known to go about with trol-my-dames: I knew him once a servant of the Prince; he hath been since an ape bearer, then a process server, a bailiff; then he compast a motion of the prodigal son, and married a tin∣ker's wife within a mile where my land and living lies; and having flown over many knavish profes∣sions, he settled only in rogue; some call him Au∣tolicus.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Out upon him, prig for my life, prig;—he haunts wakes, fairs, and bear-baitings.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Very true, Sir; he, Sir, he; that's the rogue that put me into this apparel.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Not a more cowardly rogue in all Bohemia; if you had but look'd big, and spit at him, he'd have run.

SP.SPEAKER: ANTOLICUS.
SP.P: I must confess to you, Sir, I am no fighter; I am false of heart that way; and that he knew, I warrant him.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: How do you do now?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Sweet Sir, much better than I was; I can stand and walk; I will e'en take my leave of you, and pace softly towards my kinsman's.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Shall I bring thee on thy way?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: No good-fac'd Sir; no good Sir; no sweet Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Then farewell—I must go buy spices for our sheep-shearing.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P:
Prosper you, sweet Sir. Your purse is not hot enough to purchase your spice. I'll be with you at your sheep-shearing too—If I make not this cheat bring out another, and the shearers prove sheep, let
me be unrol'd, and my name put into the book of virtue.

DIV1.HEAD: SONG.
DIV1.L: Jog or, jog on, the foot-path way,
And merrily bend the style—a—
A merry heart goes all the day,
Your sad tires in a mile—a—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. A prospect of a shepherd's cottage.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: THESE your unusual weeds, to each part of you
Do give a life; no shepherdess but Flora,
Peering in April's front, this your sheep-shearing▪
Is as a meeting of the petty gods,
And you the queen on't.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: How I bless the time,
When my good Faulcon made her flight across
Thy father's ground.

SP.SPEAKER: PERDITA.
SP.L: Now Jove afford you cause!
To me the difference forges dread: your greatness
Hath not been us'd to fear; ev'n now I tremble
To think your father, by some accident,
Shou'd pass this way as you did.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: Apprehend
Nothing but jolity. Your guests are coming:
Lift up your countenance; as 'twere the day
Of celebration of that nuptial, which
We two have sworn shall come.

SP.SPEAKER: PERDITA.
SP.L: O lady fortune,
Stand thou auspicious!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter OLD SHEPHERD, CLOWN, MOPSA, DORCAS; with POLIXENES, CAMILLO, and servants. PO∣LIXENES and CAMILLO, disguis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEPHERD.
SP.L: Fie, daughter, when my old wife liv'd, upon
This day, she was bn pantler, butler, cook,
Both dame and servant; welcom'd all, serv'd all;
Wou'd sing her song, and dance her turn.
You are retir'd,
As if you were a feasted one; pray you, bid
These unknown friends to's welcome, and present yourself,
That which you are, mistress o'th' feast: come on,
And bid us welcome to your sheep-shearing.

SP.SPEAKER: PERDITA.
SP.L: Sirs, welcome.
It is my father's will, I shou'd take on me
The hostess-ship o'th' day; you're welcome, sirs.
Give me those flowers there, Dorcas; reverend sirs,
For you there's rosemary, and rue; these keep
Seeming and favour all the winter long:
Grace and remembrance be unto you both,
And welcome to our shearing.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLO.
SP.L: I shou'd leave grazing were I of your flock,
And only live by gazing.

SP.SPEAKER: PERDITA.
SP.L: Out, alas!
You'd be so lean, that blasts of January,
Wou'd blow you thro' and thro'—now my fairest friend,
I wou'd I had some flowers o'th' spring, that might
Become your time of day: o'these, I lack
To make you garlands of, my sweet friend,
And strow you o'er and o'er.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.P: What? like a coarse?

SP.SPEAKER: PERDITA.
SP.P: No, like a bank, for love to lie and play on.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.L: Come, daughter, clear up your pipes, and call,
As custom is, our neighbours to your shearing.

SP.SPEAKER: PERDITA.
SP.P: I will obey you.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: Come, come, my good shepherds, our flocks we must shear;
In your holy-day suits, with you lasses appear:
The happiest of folk are the guiltless and free,
And who are so guiltless, so happy as we?

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: We harbour no passions, by luxury taught;
We practise no arts, with hipocrisy fraught;
What we think in our hearts, you may read in our eyes;
For knowing no falsehood we need no disguise.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: That giant, ambition, we never can dread;
Our roofs are too low for so lofty a head;
Content and sweet chearfulness open our door,
They smile with the simple and feed with the poor.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: When love has possess'd us, that love we reveal;
Like the flocks that we feed, are the passions we feel;
So harmless and simple we sport and we play,
And leave to fine folks to deceive and betray.

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.L: This is the prettiest low born lass that ever
Ran on the green-sord.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLO.
SP.L: Good sooth she is,
The queen of curds and cream.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Come on—our dance—strike up.

SP.SPEAKER: DORCAS.
SP.L: Mopsa must be your mistress, marry buy some
Garlick to mend her kissing with.

SP.SPEAKER: MOPSA.
SP.P: Now, in good time, musk will not mend thine,

SP.SPEAKER: DORCAS.
SP.P: Thou art a false man; did'st not thou swear, (it was but yesternight in the cellar, over the dove house) now that at your shearing, you wou'd this day shame Mopsa,—and—

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Hold ye, maidens, hold ye—not a word—we stand upon our manners here,—come strike up.

SP.SPEAKER: MOPSA.
SP.P: Here's to do; marry I'll swear he promis'd me long enough afore that in the hay field—more nor that, you promis'd me gloves, and ribbands, and knacks at the fair—and more nor that—

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Not a word; not a word more, wenches.

SP.SPEAKER: DORCAS.
SP.P:
Marry, come up! others have had promises, as well as some—but I have heard old folks in the
parish say, that some folks have been proud and courtly, and false-hearted ever since some folk's father found a pot of money by the sea-side here. —But I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Come, come, strike up.

DIV3.STAGE: A dance of shepherds and shepherdesses. (POLIXENES and OLD SHEPHERD talk apart.)

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: O, Master, if you did but hear the pedlar at the door; he sings several tunes faster than you'll tell money; he utters them, as he had eaten ballads, and all mens ears grow to his tunes.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: He cou'd never come better; he shall come in; I love a ballad but even too well; if it be doleful matter merrily set down; or a very pleasant thing indeed, and sung lamentably.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: He hath songs for a man or woman of all sizes; he has the prettiest love-songs for maids, with such delicate burthens of jump her and thump her: he makes the maid to answer—Whoop, do me no harm, good man—Whoop do me no harm, good man.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Prithee, bring him in, and let him approach sing∣ing.

Q.L: Lawn as white as driven snow,
Cyprus, black as e'er was crow;
Gloves, as sweet as damask roses,
Mask for faces and the noses;
For my lads to give their dears:
Pins, and poaking sticks of steel,
What maids lack from head to heel:
Come buy, of me come; come buy, come buy,
Buy lads or else your lasses cry.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: If I were not in love with Mopsa, thou shou'd'st take no money of me; but being enthralled as I am, it will also be the bondage of certain ribbands and gloves.

SP.SPEAKER: MOPSA.
SP.P: I was promis'd them against the feast, but they are come too late now.

SP.SPEAKER: DORCAS.
SP.P: He hath promis'd you more than that, or there be liars.

SP.SPEAKER: MOPSA.
SP.P: He hath paid you all he promis'd you; may be he hath given you more, which will shame you to give him again.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Is there no manners left among you maids? clamour your tongues, and not a word more. What hast here? ballads?

SP.SPEAKER: MOPSA.
SP.L: Pray now buy some, I love a ballad in print,
Or a life; for then we are sure they are true.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Here's one to a very doleful tune, how a usurer's wife was brought to bed with twenty money bags at a burthen, and how she long'd to eat adders heads, and toads carbonado'd.

SP.SPEAKER: MOPSA.
SP.P: Is it true, think you?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Here's the midwife's name to it; and five or six honest wives that were present. Why shou'd I carry lies abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: MOPSA.
SP.P: Pray, you now, buy it.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Come on; lay it by; let's first see more ballads; We'll buy other things anon.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P:
Here's another ballad of a fish, that appear'd upon the coast on Wednesday, the fourscore of April, forty thousand fathom above water, and sung this ballad, against the hard hearts of maids: it was thought she was a woman, and turn'd into a cold
fish, for she wou'd not exchange flesh with one that lov'd her: the ballad is very pitiful, and as true.

SP.SPEAKER: DORCAS.
SP.P: Is it true, too, think you?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Five justices hands at it; and witnesses more than my pack will hold.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Lay it by too—Another.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: This is a merry ballad, but a very pretty one.

SP.SPEAKER: MOPSA.
SP.P: Let's have some merry ones.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Why this is a passing merry one, and goes to the tune of two maids wooing a man: there's scarce a maid westward but she sings it: 'tis in request, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Nicholas, Dorcas, and Mopsa, can sing that: we had the tune on't a month ago—Come Nicholas, strike up.

SP.L: Get you hence, for I must go,
Where it fits not you to know.

SP.P: Whither?
O Whither?
Whiter?

SP.L: It becomes thy oath full well,
Thou to me thy secrets tell;

SP.P: Me too, let me go thither:
Or thou go'st to the grange, or mill,
If to either thou do'st ill.
Neither,
what neither?
neither.
Thou hast sworn my love to be;
Thou hast sworn it more to me:
Then, whither goest? say whither?

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.L: We'll have this song out anon by ourselves:
My father and the gentlemen are in sad talk,
And we'll not trouble them: come, bring away
The pack after me. Wenches I'll buy for you both:
Pedlar, let's have the first choice. Follow me, girls.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: And you shall pay well for 'em.Aside.

DIV1.HEAD: SONG. Dr. ARNE.
DIV1.L: Will you buy any tape, or lace for your cape?
My dainty duck my dear—a
And silk and thread? any toys for your head,
Of the newest end finest ware a —?
Come to the pedlar! money's a medar,
That doth utter all mens ware a——

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES
SP.L: How now, fair shepherd;To Flor.
Your heart is full of something that does take
Your mind from feasting. Sooth, when I was young,
And handed love as you do, I would have ransack'd
The pedlar's silken treasury, and have pour'd it
To her acceptance; you have let him go,
And nothing marted with him.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: Old Sir, I know:
She prizes not such trifles as these are:
The gifts she looks from me, are packt and lockt
Up in my heart; which I have given already,
But not deliver'd. O hear me breathe my love
Before this ancient Sir.

LG.L: Witness O Earth, and Heav'ns, and all!
Were at my feet this earthly ball,
Were I more fair than e'er charm'd eye,
Only for her I'd live and die.
Had I beyond all mortals force,
Of knowledge cou'd I drain each source,
Did every blessing on me fall,
Only for her I'd use them all.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.L: But, my daughter,
Think you the like of him?

SP.SPEAKER: PERDITA.
SP.P: By the pattern of my own thoughts, I cut out the purity of his.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.L: Take hands—a bargain;
And friends, unknown, you shall bear witness to't.

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.L: Soft, swain, a-while; 'beseech you,
Have you a father?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.P: I have; but what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.P: Knows he of this?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.P: He neither does, nor shall.

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.L: Methinks a father
Is, at the nuptial of his son, a guest
That best becomes the table.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: I yield all this:
But for some reasons 'tis not fit, you know;
"I not acquaint my father of this business."

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.P: Let him know't.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.P: He shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.P: Prithee, let him.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.P: No; he must not.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.L: Let him, my son, he shall not need to grieve
At knowing of thy choice.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: Come, come, he must not:
Mark our contract.

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.P: Mark your divorce, young Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: LEONTES.
SP.P: How! Polixenes! what myst'ry is this!

DIV3.STAGE: Leans on Cleomines, and they go apart.

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.L: And thou, old traitor,To the Old Shep.
I'm sorry, that by hanging thee, I can but
Shorten thy life one week. For thee, fond boy,
Follow us to the court—and you enchantment
Worthy enough a herdsman; if e'er, thou
These rural latches to his entrance open,
Or hoop his body more with thy embraces,
I will devise a death as cruel for thee,
As thou art tender to it.Exit. Pol. and Cam.

SP.SPEAKER: LEONTES.
SP.L: How now, old father?
Good shepherd, speak.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.L: I cannot speak, nor think—O Sir,To Flor.
You have undone a man of fourscore three,
That thought to fill his grave in quiet; yea,
To die upon the bed my father dy'd,
To lie close by his honest bones; but now—
Thou knew'st this was the prince, and wou'dst ad∣venture.
To mingle faith with him—Undone! undone!

SP.SPEAKER: PERDITA.
SP.P: O my poor father!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: Why look you so upon me?
I am but sorry, not afraid; delay'd,
But nothing alter'd—lift up thy looks!
From my succession, let my father blot me,
I'm heir to my affection.

SP.SPEAKER: LEONTES.
SP.L: Passion transports you, prince; be calm a while,
Nor scorn my years and seeming, but attend;—
Trust to my words, tho' myst'ry obscures 'em—
I know the king your father, and if time,
And many accidents (cease foolish tears)
Have not effac'd my image from his breast,
Perhaps he'll listen to me.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: O reverend Sir!
As you wou'd wish a child of your own youth
To meet his happiness in love, speak for me;
Step forth my advocate.

SP.SPEAKER: LEONTES.
SP.L: I lost a daughter, that 'twixt heav'n and earth
Might thus have stood begetting wonder, as
Yon lovely maiden does—of that no more;—
I'll to the king your father—this our compact,
Your honour not o'erthrown by your desires,
I am a friend to them and you.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: Dear, look up;
Tho' fortune, visible an enemy,
Shou'd chace us with my father; power, no jot
Hath she to change our loves.

DIV1.HEAD: SONG. Dr. ARNOLD.
DIV1.L: Once more I swear, not all the worth
Of wide Bohemia's realm;
Not all the sun beholds, the earth
Contains, or seas o'erwhelm;
No friend, no father's hand controul,
My firm resolves an shake:
Can ever move my constant soul,
My plighted oath to break,

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III. Another part of the Country.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: HOW fortune drops into the mouth of the di∣ligent man, —see, if I be not transform'd courtier again—four silken gamesters, who attended the king, and were revelling by themselves, at some distance from the shepherds, have drank so plenti∣fully, that their weak brains are turn'd topsy-tur∣vy—I found one of 'em, an old court comrade of mine, retir'd from the rest, sobering himself with sleep under the shade of a hawthorn; I made use of our antient familiarity to exchange garments with him; the pedlar's clothes are on his back, and the pack by his side, as empty as his pockets, for I have sold all my trumpery; not a counter∣feit stone, nor a ribband, glass, pomander, browch, table-book, ballad, knife, tape, glove, shoe-tie, bracelet, horn; they throng'd who shou'd buy first. I pick'd out and cut most of their festival purses; and had not the old man come in with a whoo-bub against his daughter and the king's son, and scar'd my choughs from the chaff, I had not left a purse alive in the whole army—aside, aside, here is more matter for a hot brain.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: See, see, what a man you are now—there is no other way, but to tell the king she is a changeling, and none of your flesh and blood.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Nay, but hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Nay, but hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Go to, then—

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Let him know the truth of the matter; how you found her by the sea-side some eighteen years agone; that there was this bundle with her, with the things and trinkets contained therein; but there was some money too, which being spent in nursing her, you need say nothing about it, to∣gether with all the circumstances of the whole af∣fair; do it, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: And what then, think'st thou?

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Why then, she being none of your flesh and blood, your flesh and blood has not offended the king, and so your flesh and blood is not to be pu∣nish'd by him: shew those things.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: I will tell the king all, every word; yea, and his son's pranks too; who, I may say, is no honest man, neither to his father nor me, to go about to make me the king's brother-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Indeed, brother-in-law was the farthest off you cou'd have been to him; and then your blood had been the dearer, by I know not how much an ounce.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.L: Very wisely, puppies.Coming forward.
How now, rustics, whither are you bound?

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: To th' palace, an' it like your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Your affairs there? what? with whom? the con∣dition of that fardel, the place of your dwelling, your names, your age, of what having, breeding, and any thing that is fitting to be known, disco∣ver.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Are you a courtier, an' like you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Whether it like me or no, I am a courtier— see'st thou not the air of the court in these enfold∣ings? hath not my gait in it the measure of the court? receives not thy nose court-odour from me? reflect not I on thy baseness, court-contempt? whereupon, I command thee to open thy affair.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: My business, sir, is to the king.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: What advocate hast thou to him?

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Advocate!Aside to Clown.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Advocate's the court word for a pheasant; say you have none.Apart.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: None, sir; I have no pheasant, cock nor hen.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.L: How blest are we, that are not simple men!
Yet nature might have made me as these are,
Therefore I will not disdain.Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN,
SP.P: This cannot be but a great courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: His garments are rich, but he wears 'em not handsomely.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: He seems to be more noble in being fantasti∣cal; a great man, I'll warrant, I know by the picking on's teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.L: The fardel there, what's in the fardel?
Wherefore that box?

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Sir, there lies such secrets in this fardel and box, which none must know but the king; and which he shall know within this hour, if I may come to th' speech of him.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Age, thou hast lost thy labour.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Why, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: The king is not at the palace, he's gone aboard a new ship to purge melancholy, and air himself; for if thou be'st capable of things serious, thou must know the king is full of grief.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: So, 'tis said, Sir, about his son that shou'd have marry'd a shepherd's daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: If that shepherd be not in hand fast, let him sly. An old sheep whistling rogue, a ram-tender, to offer to have his daughter come into grace!— Some say he shall be ston'd; but that death is too soft for him, say I: draw our throne into a sheep∣cot! all deaths are too few, the sharpest too easy.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: I thank you, Sir,Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Has the old man e'er a son, Sir, do you hear, an't like you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: He has a son, who shall be stay'd alive, then 'nionted over with honey, set on the head of a wasp's nest; then stand till he be three quarters and a dram dead; then recover'd again with aqua-vita, or some other infusion; then (raw as he is, and in the hottest day prognostication proclaims) shall be set against a brick wall, the sun looking with a southward eye upon him, where he is to behold him with flies, blown to death; but what talk we of these traitorly rascals, whose miseries are to be smil'd at, their offences being so capital? tell me, (for you seem to be honest, plain men) what you have to the King; being something gently consider'd, I'll bring you where he is, and if it be in man, besides the king, to effect your suits, here is a man shall do it.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: He seems to be of great authority, close with him, give him gold; tho' authority be a stubborn bear, yet he is often led by the nose with gold; shew the inside of your purse to the outside of his hand, and no more ado; remember ston'd and flay'd alive.Aside to Old Shep.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: And't please you, Sir, to undertake the business for us, here is that gold I have; I'll make it as much more, and leave this young man in pawn 'till I bring it you.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Well, give me the moiety—are you a party in this business?

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: In some, sort, Sir: but tho' my case be a pitiful one, I hope I shall not be flay'd out of it.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: O, that's the case of the shepherd's son; hang him, he'll be made an example.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN
SP.P: Comfort! good comfort! Sir, I will give you as much as this old man does, when the business is perform'd, and remain, as he says your pawn 'till it be brought you.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: I will trust you; walk before toward the sea-side; go on the right hand, I will but look upon the hedge, and follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: We are blest in this man, as I may say, ev'n blest.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Let's before as he bids us; he was provided to do us good.Eeunt Shep. and Clown.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P:
If I had a mind to be honest, I see fortune wou'd not suffer me; she drops booties into my mouth —I am courted now with a double occasion: gold, and a means to do the king good; which, who knows how that may turn to my advancement! I will bring these two moles, these blind ones before him; if that the complaint to the king concerns him nothing, let him call me rogue for being o
far officious; I am proof against that title, and what shame else belongs to it: to him I will pre∣sent them; there may be matter in it.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, PAULINA's House.

SP.SPEAKER: PAULINA.
SP.P: Leontes arriv'd! escap'd from the fury of the sea! veil'd in the 'semblance of a poor shepherd! and has thrown himself into the arms of Polixenes! 'tis a chain of wonders!

SP.SPEAKER: GENT.
SP.P: Yet the tale is not more wonderful than true; I was present at the interview.—Here comes the good Camillo; speak, thou bear'st thy tydings in thy looks.

DIV3.L: O, Paulina, the beatings of my heart will scarce
Permit my tongue to tell thee what it bears.

SP.SPEAKER: PAULINA.
SP.P: I know it all, my friend; the king of Sicily is arriv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLO.
SP.P: Not only the king of Sicily is arriv'd, but his daughter; his long-lost daughter, is found!

SP.SPEAKER: PAULINA.
SP.P: His daughter found! Can it be? how was she sav'd? and where has she been concealed?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLO.
SP.P: That shepherdess, our prince has so long and so secretly affected, proves Sicilia's heiress: the old shepherd, her suppos'd father, deliver'd the man∣ner how he found her upon the coast, produc'd a fardel, in which are uncontested proofs of every circumstance.

SP.SPEAKER: PAULINA.
SP.P: Praised be the gods! wou'd I had beheld the behaviour of the two kings at the unravelling of this story.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLO.
SP.P: Ay, Paulina, for you have lost a sight, which was to be seen—cannot be spoken of.

SP.SPEAKER: PAULINA.
SP.P: Are they returned to court?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLO.
SP.P: Not yet. They were proceeding with due ce∣remony, amid the clamorous joy of the multitude, when I took advantage of their delay, to recount to you this rhapsody of wonders.Trumpets.

SP.SPEAKER: PAULINA.
SP.P: Camillo, haste thee; this royal assembly is en∣tring now the city.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLO.
SP.P: I obey you, madam.Exeunt severally.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Now, had I not the dash of my former life in me, wou'd preferment fall upon my head. I brought the old man and his son to the king's, and told them, I heard them talk of a fardel, and I know not what—but 'tis all one to me; for had I been the finder out of this secret, it wou'd not have relish'd among my other discredits—here come those I have done good to against my will, and already appearing in the blossoms of their for∣tune.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter OLD SHEP. and CLOWN, fantastically dressed.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Come boy; I am past more children; but thy sons and daughters will be all gentlemen born.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN, to AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: You are well met, sir; you denied that I was a gentleman born; see these clothes! say you see them not, and think me still no gentleman born— give me the iie, do—and try whether I am now no gentleman born.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: I know you are now, sir, a gentleman born.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Ay, and have been so, for any time this half hour.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: And so have I, boy.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: So you have; but I was a gentleman born be∣fore my father; for the king's son took me by the hand and call'd me brother; and then, the prince, my brother, and the princess, my sister, (that is, that was my sister) called my father, fa∣ther; and so we all wept: and there was the first gentleman-like tears that ever we shed.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: We may live, son, to shed many more.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Ay, or else 'twere hard luck, being in so pre∣posterous estate as we are.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: I humbly beseech you, sir, to pardon all the faults I have committed to your worship; and to give me your good report to the prince my mas∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: Prithee, son, do; for we must be gentle, now we are gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Thou wilt amend thy life.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Ay, an' it like your good worship.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: No, it does not like my worship now; but it is like it may be like my worship when it is amend∣ed; therefore have heed that thou do'st amend it.

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: I will, an't like you.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Give me thy hand; hast nothing in't? am not I a gentleman? I must be gently consider'd—am not I a courtier? seest thou not the air of the court in these enfoldings? hath not my gait in it the measure of the court?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: Here is what gold I have, Sir;—so, I have brib'd him with his own money.Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: And when am I to have the other moiety? and the young man in pawn till you bring it me?

SP.SPEAKER: AUTOLICUS.
SP.P: After you have done the business, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Well, I will swear to the prince, thou art as ho∣nest a tall fellow as any in Bohemia.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: You may say it, but not swear it.

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: Not swear it, now I am a gentleman? let boors and franklyns say it; I'll swear it.

SP.SPEAKER: OLD SHEP.
SP.P: How, if it be false, son?

SP.SPEAKER: CLOWN.
SP.P: If it be never so false, a true gentleman may swear it in behalf of his friend; and I will swear to the prince thou art a tall fellow of thy hands, and that thou wilt not be drunk; but I know thou art no tall fellow of thy hands, and thou wilt be drunk; but I'll swear it; no matter for that. Trumpets. Hark! the kings, and the princes, our kindred. Come, follow us, we will be thy good masters.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, PAULINA's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter LEONTES, POLIXENES, FLORIZEL, PER∣DITA, CAMILLO, Lords, Attendants, and PAU∣LINA.

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.L: Sir, you have done enough, and have per∣form'd
A saint-like sorrow: no fault cou'd you make
Which you have not redeem'd; indeed paid down
More penitence, than done trespass. At the last
Do, as the heav'ns have done, forget your evil;
With them forgive yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: LEONTES.
SP.L: Oh! if penitence
Have pow'r to cleanse the foul sin-spotted soul,
Leontes' tears have wash'd away his guilt.
If thanks unfeign'd be all that you require,
Most bounteous gods, for happiness like mine,
Read in my heart, your mercy's not in vain.
This firstling duty paid, let transport loose,
Thou, Perdita, my long-lost child, that fill'st
My measure up of bliss
My Polixenes, my injur'd friend!
Your pardon and your love.—
Again I challenge, this my son-in-law,
Long troth-plight to our daughter.

DIV3.STAGE: LEONTES and POLIXENES join their hands.

SP.SPEAKER: POLIXENES.
SP.P: Be all that's past in this their union cancell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: PERDITA.
SP.L: I am all shame
And ignorance itself, how to put on
This novel garment of gentility,
And yield a patch'd behaviour, between
My country level, and my present fortunes,
That ill becomes this presence. I shall learn,
I trust I shall with meekness—but I feel,
(Ah happy that I do) a love, an heart
Unaltered to my prince, my Florizel.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIZEL.
SP.L: Be still my queen of May, my shepherdess,
Rule in my heart; my wishes be thy subjects,
And harmless as thy sheep.

DIV1.HEAD: CHORUS.
DIV1.L: Come, let us all be blythe and gay,
Upon this happy wedding day,
That Florizel weds Perdita,
And let each nymph and shepherd tell,
No happy pair e'er lov'd so well,
As Perdita and Florizel.
